body: A 24-year-old car service employee who rushed to the aid of a neighboring Brooklyn merchant during a robbery was shot twice in the head on Monday afternoon and left in extremely critical condition, the police said. The employee, whose name was not released, tried to stop two men from robbing a cellphone store on Avenue Z at Coney Island Avenue in
title: Brooklyn Car Service Worker Is Shot in Head While Trying to Foil Robbery

body: When he's crashed the chandelier of the Paris Opera House and driven away the woman he loves with the sight of his abhorrent face, where does a musically gifted phantom go for a little R&R? Brooklyn, of course. In an interview with The Times of London, Andrew Lloyd Webber said that a recently completed sequel to his musical ''The Phantom of the
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; A Half-Masked Man To Ride the Q Train

body: Eleven years after an off-duty police officer was assassinated by gunmen lying in wait outside his home in Sheepshead Bay, federal prosecutors charged three accused mob figures on Thursday in the shooting, removing a high-profile murder from the ranks of unsolved cases while painting the motive as one of simple romantic jealousy. The charges were
title: 11 Years After Officer's Slaying, Reputed Mob Figures Are Indicted

body: ''The Nutcracker'' isn't a Christmas tradition worldwide: in France and most of Europe this ballet is performed infrequently, and in South Africa, where I grew up, other Christmas-theme ballets, like a Hans Christian Andersen-inspired ''Snow Queen,'' were just as popular. But in the United States the pattern was set by George Balanchine, who
title: DANCE; Land of Sugarplums Is the Bread and Butter of the Holiday Season

body: Since 2000, the number of young children living in parts of Lower Manhattan has nearly doubled. The poverty rate declined in all but one New York City neighborhood. A majority of Bronx residents are Hispanic. And the number of white people living in Harlem more than tripled, helping to drive up median household income there by nearly 20 percent --
title: City Growing More Diverse, Census Finds

body: DOPPELT--Minnie, of Whippany, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, died peacefully in her sleep Saturday December 6, at the age of 90. With her husband Jacob Doppelt, she was active in support of the Yeshivah of Flatbush, and served as President of its Ladies Auxiliary. She was a life member and officer of AMIT. She is survived by her brother, Rabbi Abraham
title: Paid Notice: Deaths DOPPELT, MINNIE

body: It is the city's most monumental art collection. Literally. For the last four years, Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, the 170-year-old resting place of entombed luminaries from Boss Tweed to Leonard Bernstein and the original Brooks brothers, has been acquiring paintings created by the artists -- both legendary and obscure -- who have taken up
title: Works by Resident Artists

body: WEINREB--Phyllis, on December 1, at age 84. Beloved wife of Dr. Herbert Weinreb. Loving mother of Daniel (Cheryl), William (Lisa), and David. Adoring grandmother of Adam, Caleb, Gabriel, Susannah, Talia and Elizabeth. Graduate of Brooklyn College and the Columbia School of Social Work. She was always kind, warm and generous, and devoted to her
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WEINREB, PHYLLIS

body: The church custodian saw him first: a man alone in a parking lot, swinging a folding chair like an ax, bringing it down toward the windshield of a parked van and stopping, an inch from the glass. Then backing up and dancing around with the chair, a strange ballet. Then swinging again, over and over. The custodian yelled for the man to stop, and
title: A Flash of Menace, and a Death by Police Bullet

body: Stacey Wexler and Kevin Kotler were married Wednesday at the New York City Municipal Building in Manhattan. Blanca Martinez, a staff member in the City Clerk's office, officiated. The couple are to have a Jewish ceremony on Dec. 5 at the Curtain Bluff Resort in Old Road Village in Antigua, West Indies. Jerry Kotler, an uncle of the bridegroom, who
title: Stacey Wexler, Kevin Kotler

body: THE evening usually starts with an unmarked door, poorly lighted stairs and a familiar popping sound. Table tennis. Wally Green, 29, from the Marlboro Houses in Coney Island, picked up the game after losing money to pool hall hustlers. Susan Sarandon, the actress, discovered the game through her son Miles, 16. She and Mr. Green find themselves at
title: Back-and-Forth Sport Is Back Again

body: STACHEL--Diana, beloved wife of Dr. Sheldon D., devoted mother of Denise Heimerle, Paul Stachel and Maxine Stachel. Sister of Brenda Rudowitz. Loving grandmother. Services Friday, 10am, Weinstein-Garlick-Kirschenbaum, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

body: The fleet's in this weekend, at least on 55th Street, where a radiant production of ''On the Town'' has docked at City Center through Sunday. Hop aboard the celestial subway train of Leonard Bernstein's piping, pumping, altogether transporting music -- this was the first of his handful of Broadway shows -- and you'll be whisked back to a time when
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'ON THE TOWN'; Drop Me Off at Broadway, 1944

body: Lyle Pinder and Rachel Hoskins took their first tentative salsa steps not far from their apartment on the windswept, once-industrial riverbank of Long Island City, Queens. But they were not exploring the gritty neighborhood, where they recently joined what was once a trickle of urban pioneers. They just took the elevator from their apartment to the
title: LONG ISLAND CITY JOURNAL; When Home Is More Like a Cruise Ship

body: At first glance, the standoff that led to the death of Gilberto Blanco in a Coney Island parking lot on Thursday appeared mismatched. He had a chair. A police officer had a gun. During a confrontation, the officer fatally shot him. In a preliminary review on Friday, the Police Department found that the actions of the officer, Dawn Ortiz, 33,
title: Police Defend Shooting Of Man Swinging a Chair

body: A man who charged at a police officer with a wooden folding chair in a church parking lot in Coney Island was shot to death on Thursday afternoon by the officer, the authorities said. The police said they had not identified the man as of Thursday evening, saying only that he appeared to be in his 20s. He had been seen trying to break into a van in
title: Man Who Tried to Hit Officer With a Chair Is Shot to Death

body: JOE THE PLUMBER spent Election Day running vent lines for a new McDonald's going up in Coney Island, chomping a breakfast of baby carrots as he hauled 10-foot lengths of four-inch No-Hub pipe from his van to the construction site around the corner. A few miles away, Joe the Plumber spent Election Day inspecting the boiler at a French-Caribbean
title: What About Joe?

author: E-mail: geovec@nytimes.com
body: On the day after the New York City Marathon, the roadway in Central Park was still a special place, almost a shrine, to the millions of feet that have padded through. Moving gingerly but proudly, runners dressed in comfortable clothing returned to the park Monday to have their pictures taken in front of the finish line they had crossed a day
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Marathon Remains on the Right Course

body: JOE SITT received a degree in business at New York University in the 1980s, which helped him become a real estate powerhouse. But he also took courses in history, and that subject, he said, has had an influence on how he sees his work as a developer. ''One of my philosophies is that what 'once was' can be again,'' he said. In New York, where Mr.
title: CHECKING IN; A Hotel Looks Back To Its 1920's Glamour

body: A man who was being arrested for using a student MetroCard on Tuesday evening struggled with two plainclothes police officers in a Queens subway station and then shot them with the gun of one of the officers, the police said. The gunman was then shot by the officers' supervisor, the police said. ''The whole thing lasted probably 45 seconds,'' said
title: 2 Plainclothes Officers Shot in Queens Subway Station

body: The Canada geese fly into Frederick Douglass Memorial Park every morning, leaving their droppings on the decrepit asphalt roads and their webbed prints on the small grave markers lying flat against the soft ground. These days, they are the most frequent visitors. The park, an African-American cemetery nearly filled to capacity, surrounded by
title: RICHMOND TOWN JOURNAL; A Place of Dignity Falls on Hard Times

body: An article and a headline in some editions on Thursday about New York City's purchase of land in Coney Island, Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to the one-acre parcel. It is inside Wonder Wheel Amusement Park, but it is not the site of the Wonder Wheel itself. (That land is still owned by the Vourderis family, which operates the ride.)
title: Corrections

body: New York City has bought the one-acre site of the Wonder Wheel for $11 million as part of the Bloomberg administration's plan to preserve the historic character of Coney Island, the city announced on Wednesday. The city said that it expected to acquire additional land from local owners in the coming months. The property joins the Cyclone roller
title: Trying to Uphold Coney Island's Character, City Buys Wonder Wheel Site

body: Olafur Eliasson, the Danish-Icelandic artist who created the four waterfall exhibits on the East River, has said that he wanted people looking at them to reconsider their relationship to the surroundings. Scott Stamford has been doing just that, though not in the way Mr. Eliasson intended. Mr. Stamford is the manager of the River Café, a popular
title: Waterfalls Exit, but With Unintended Impact

body: On a recent day on the boulevard that stretches from the heart of Brooklyn to the sea, a young teacher helped his daughters with schoolwork, a man hurled Russian insults and coins at an elderly woman who he thought was driving too slowly, and a man from Bedford-Stuyvesant read a tabloid for hours, having only just discovered, after 46 years, the
title: BROOKLYN JOURNAL; A Tree-Lined Boulevard That's a Park and a Living Room

But the large influx of African and Arab immigrants into the poorer neighborhoods outside Paris, unknown to most Americans until the 2005 riots, has
title: Spare Times

body: WHEN Englishmen in 1816 gave the area midway between Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and Jamaica, Queens, the rather uncreative name of Middle Village, it seemed they ensured that it would largely stay off people's maps. Not that the residents are complaining. ''It's a very consistent neighborhood,'' said Gary Giordano, who has been district manager of the
title: LIVING IN | MIDDLE VILLAGE, QUEENS; A Halfway Point Where People Tend to Stay

body: When the third season of ''Ugly Betty'' begins on Thursday, viewers who see the show's star, America Ferrera, stumble past the Brooklyn Bridge or the Empire State Building will be seeing something new: New York. Until this season, the ABC show was produced in Los Angeles, where its exterior shots were frequently filmed in front of green screens,
title: Thanks to Tax Credits, the New York You See on TV Is More Likely the Real City

title: Paid Notice: Deaths LEVY, SHIRLEY R.

The woman, Anya Sapozhnikova, was performing her aerial
title: Need a Party Livened Up? Try a Fire Eater or Two

It is a testament to the vitality of the Brooklyn literary scene that the reading is not the signature
title: Spare Times

body: FIVE in the morning down at the deli, Knapp Street, Brooklyn, the smell of the tide coming in soft and funky over Jordan's Lobster Dock down the block. People stand in line for coffee, ice, a sandwich for later. There is nervous energy in the air, guys shuffling in boots and flip-flops. Here are rumpled fishing guides ripped from the womb of sleep
title: A Short Cast Away

body: An empty lot in Coney Island is not the likeliest place for an electronic music festival. But then New York City isn't the likeliest place for an electronic music festival either. For years the tightly knit collection of techno fans here has complained that their scene is underrepresented, with only a few regularly scheduled club nights dedicated
title: New York's Great Big Party for Technoheads

body: Depression has no place in an amusement park, but a definite pall hung over Astroland at Coney Island on Sunday, even as the screams of thrill seekers -- grade-school children, metal-mouthed teenagers and nostalgic, if slightly nauseated, grownups -- tore through the air. On Thursday, the park's owner, Carol Albert, announced that Sunday would be
title: Summer Without Astroland?

body: 8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: KAY FRANCIS She was the most popular actress at Warner Brothers before Bette Davis came along. This month Turner Classic Movies pays tribute each Thursday to Francis, an Oklahoma girl whose dark, statuesque beauty -- at 5 feet 9 inches she was the tallest leading lady in 1930s Hollywood -- and velvety voice helped
title: WHAT'S ON TODAY

body: If all goes according to plan this weekend at the Toronto International Film Festival, voices caught on tape at a Manhattan rap session more than 33 years ago will introduce a film about the making of ''A Chorus Line.'' Those voices, and others from a handful of movies at this sprawling, 10-day film festival opening on Thursday, are also likely to
title: A Nostalgia for New York, by Way of the Toronto Film Festival

body: With high-rise projects stretching against the horizon, sea gulls pecking at drifting refuse and more cigarette butts than seashells in the sand, Brooklyn's beaches are not exactly known for their resortlike experience. But on Brighton Beach, sunbathers can have a taste of cabana-style service by motioning to a hulking figure lugging a worn bag in
title: Under the Table, Under the Boardwalk

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: More Fire Response Q.When I see fire trucks responding to incidents, there always seem to be more vehicles and more commotion than I remember from childhood. Why is that? A. Fewer false alarms and more emergencies requiring special treatment. ''The number of units that are dispatched for a reported fire on the initial alarm today is the same number
title: F. Y. I.

body: Eduard and Julia Brodsky, immigrants from Ukraine, went to a handball court in Brooklyn and started hitting tennis balls with rackets. Gail, their only child, watched with big eyes. ''I said I wanted to try because it looked like fun,'' she said. ''And it was. Apparently, I liked it.'' Gail Brodsky was 6 at the time and had just come to the United
title: Showing Promise in Debut as a Pro

body: At the end of the line, the subway creaks to a stop a few yards short of the yellow crash bumper. A few stragglers, or a lurch of homebound commuters, head for the street. title: Lonesomeness, Beauty, Ambition and Often an Abiding Oddness: It's the Curious World of the Last Stop

body: HERE'S a conversation you might hear (or have) on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn: ''Hey, let's get some schnitzel.'' ''Schnitzi or Schnitzel King?'' ''Schnitzi. Those guys know how to sauce a schnitzel.'' No matter what you think of schnitzel, it's fun to say. And you'll be saying more of it: Schnitzel is on the rise in New York. Schnitzi plans to
title: $25 AND UNDER; Chicken In Global Attire

body: International RAPID RESPONSE TO A RAID In a Fragile Iraq Province Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq ordered an investigation into a raid Tuesday that recalled the attacks once carried out regularly by the Shiite-dominated security forces. His rapid response reflected fears that the raid, in which a Sunni provincial governor was arrested
title: INSIDE THE TIMES: August 20, 2008

body: FROM a distance, the wide aisles crammed with organic pear juice, whole-grain cereal and trans-fat-free chips, the wood floors and red pendant lighting make Pomegranate look like any other upscale supermarket. But look closer. Next to the Jif peanut butter, there's white chocolate spread with a label in Hebrew. Abutting the panko are whole-wheat
title: Sushi and Kishke Under One Roof

body: Streaked gold and green, candy-stripe figs from California look too beautiful to eat. But slice one of these exquisite fruits in half and you'll see why Dan Spitz, the founder of the Orchard, a produce market in Brooklyn, calls them raspberry figs. The inside is the color of raspberry jam and even has a similar sweet-tart flavor and texture, thanks
title: FOOD STUFF; A Fig Reveals Its Inner Raspberry

body: The skies over Coney Island put on a spectacular show on Saturday evening, with the sunset casting violet hues and a fat yellow moon disappearing and reappearing through clouds. But for a row of spectators lined up along a lonely section of the Boardwalk, the real entertainment was happening opposite the beach, inside an ornate yet decrepit
title: CONEY ISLAND JOURNAL; Roller Skaters Revel in a New Rink in the City

body: Many of the white-haired fans who showed up on Sunday came with hearts that still ached, even after all these years, for their long-gone Dodgers team that packed up its cleats and left in 1957. The man on the mound was Carl Erskine, the star pitcher of the 1955 World Series championship Dodgers, and his presence on the field sent the old fans on a
title: Erskine Takes the Mound, And Suddenly It's 1955

body: DURING several days last August, harried denizens of Wall Street and camera-snapping tourists were given an unusual lunchtime treat: a 15-minute performance choreographed by Reggie Wilson and Andréya Ouamba for the steps of the United States Custom House on Bowling Green. Called ''Accounting for Customs,'' it was an intoxicating brew of sensual
title: DANCE; Summer in the City and Its Outdoor Spaces

body: I was at the bottom of the ocean in Brooklyn when it dawned on me why I love New York City beaches even more than those pristine, remote shores seen in vacation brochures. It was not exactly pristine or remote where I was swimming, at Brighton Beach, surrounded by a group of elderly Russians in bathing caps backstroking their afternoon away. But as
title: SUMMER IN THE CITY; Too Darn Hot? Hop the 'Sea' Train

title: If You Could Bottle A Coney Island Sideshow

body: On the back patio of an East Village apartment, Natasha Kouri sat on a bench surrounded by plastic bottles and bags. She picked up a bottle from the woman on her left, who chopped its bottom off at the Poland Spring label. Ms. Kouri wove a handful of bags through the opening and handed the work in progress to her right. A bearded man taped the bags
title: Priming for Burning Man, Flames in Hand

body: ITSIK ZEITOUNI, a young man with big ambitions, was living in the Homecrest section of southern Brooklyn early last year, but his thoughts were elsewhere -- just a little to the west, in fact, in the adjacent neighborhood of Gravesend. There, the Sephardic Jewish population was in the midst of a population boom that was ratcheting up prices for
title: LIVING IN | GRAVESEND, BROOKLYN; A Neighborhood Both Insular and Diverse

body: David Byrne is an installation artist, author, blogger, recording executive, photographer, film director and PowerPoint enthusiast. He's even been known to dabble in music. But in certain New York neighborhoods he may be most visible as a bicycle rider, a lanky figure pedaling around the Lower East Side, or from Bay Ridge out to Coney Island in
title: David Byrne, Cultural Omnivore, Raises Cycling Rack to an Art Form

body: Jose Pico, 17, just became a freak. So far, it's working out well. ''My cousin was working here as a freak, and he got fired, so they hired me,'' said Jose, who has been working for only a week at Shoot the Freak, a popular game on the Coney Island Boardwalk near Stillwell Avenue. Customers pay to shoot paint balls at a young man in full pads,
title: It's a Living: Acting Like a Freak and Getting Shot

body: New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation has signed a 10-year, $100 million contract with a profit-making medical school in the Caribbean to provide clinical training for hundreds of students at the city's 11 public hospitals. The unusual deal, proposed by a member of the corporation's board who has long worked for the Caribbean school, has
title: City Hospitals Create Outcry In Foreign Deal

author: Nathaniel Rich's first novel, ''The Mayor's Tongue,'' was published earlier this year.
body: NEW YORKERS may be prone to the flu in the winter, but in the summer the entire city comes down with a fever. Common symptoms include subway-platform fainting spells, air-conditioner sore throats, fits of sidewalk nudity, heat rash, heat migraines, heat confusion, heat rage and heat nightmares. Even the rats, lazily sampling the curb's all-night
title: His Blue Period

body: THE signs, explaining how to escape riptides, were new to Long Beach, placed along 36 entrance ramps on Monday. They were part of the city's response to three drownings in two days in Long Beach -- part of an unusually deadly weekend on Long Island beaches in which five people drowned after getting caught in rough currents. The three deaths in Long
title: Town Posts Riptide Signs After Drownings

body: The journalist Christopher Hitchens underwent waterboarding for a recent Vanity Fair article. Now an artist is using that interrogation technique -- which makes people feel as if they were drowning -- to raise awareness of the issue of torture. The artist, Steve Powers, opened ''The Waterboarding Thrill Ride'' on Saturday in the Coney Island arcade
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Waterboarding As Art

body: Separate searches continued on Sunday along parts of the New York coastline for two young swimmers swept out to sea, presumably the victims of unusually powerful riptides that have claimed at least four other lives in recent days. ''I've been doing this for 25 years, and this is the worst summer I can recall,'' said Lt. Bruce Meyer, of the Long
title: A Deadly Weekend for Swimmers in the Waters Off Brooklyn and Long Island

title: The Will Must Be as Strong as the Arm

body: Greece will join the United States men's basketball team at the Olympics in a strong Group B, which now includes all three medalists from the world championships two years ago. title: RINGS; U.S., Greece and Germany In Same Basketball Group

body: THE sand at the southern tip of New York, sad to say, is filthy. Walk down to the beach and the picture is no prettier: the remains of a case of Coors Light, some takeout containers, and a
title: DISPATCHES; The Old Beer Cans and the Sea

body: Fat pillows of viscous smoke reflected in the spotlights as Snoop Dogg took the stage on Wednesday night at Keyspan Park at Coney Island. ''Anybody smoke chronic?'' he asked, avuncularly. As he has aged Snoop Dogg has become more of a soul man than the liquid (bordering on lethargic) rapper he started out as. Backed by a band, his set was like an
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Two Acts With One Favorite Pastime

body: If one is the loneliest number, then four is the hottest -- at least when it comes to gasoline. With regular gas in New York City at a near-record $4.40 a gallon, station managers are rummaging through their storage closets in search of extra 4s to display on their pumps. Many are coming up short. That's why Vishal Nair, who runs the Lukoil station
title: A Shortage At the Pump: Not of Gas, But of 4s

body: International U.S. ANALYSTS UNIMPRESSED By Iranian Military's Bluff Iran's war games featured more bluff and exaggeration than displays of menacing new power, according to military analysts, after the release of a photo by the country showing a missile firing and misleadingstatements about the range of the largest missile. ''Deception was
title: INSIDE THE TIMES: JULY 12, 2008

body: The sun had barely pierced the indigo morning sky when Francisco J. Perez made the call. He gripped the street pay phone and spoke of his knack for spreading concrete, his expertise in carpentry, his love for painting. He paced and fidgeted, picking at his jagged, mud-encrusted fingernails, and then slammed down the receiver in triumph. On this
title: Chasing an American Dream

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites 'GOING PLACES (DOING STUFF)' Necessity breeds invention. Also, gas is expensive, and everyone loves a road trip. Thus was born ''Going Places (Doing Stuff),'' an artist-led group bus adventure and the newest project from the Flux Factory, an alternative gallery space. Since 2002 the gallery has occupied a former
title: Spare Times

body: A picture caption in some editions last Friday with vignettes of a cross section of people riding the Q train on a summer morning misidentified the Brooklyn terminus for the Q. It is in Coney Island, not Brighton Beach.
title: Corrections

body: Call it congestion parking. In what amounts to congestion pricing for parking spaces, parking meter rates would double during heavy traffic periods in portions of Manhattan and Brooklyn as part of an experimental city program beginning this fall, officials said Wednesday. The program's goal is to increase turnover in curbside parking spaces in the
title: City to Test Peak Rates for Parking Meters

body: WITH a trunk full of cod, brisket, blackberries, arugula and antifreeze, Alan Harding drives down Smith Street, past American Apparel, past the Michelin-starred restaurant Saul and past Patois, the bistro he helped open 11 years ago. Back then the neighborhood was a more likely destination for drug deals than dinner. Patois, where he was the chef,
title: Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn

body: AROUND TOWN THE FIFTH OF JULY When the oohing and aahing, not to mention the eating, are over, it might be time for a holiday reality check. In New York reminders of the War for Independence are everywhere, of course, and several events on Saturday deliver jolts from the past. On his ''Revolution in the Streets'' walking tour, Frederick Cookinham
title: Spare Times

body: Nadia Gavrylchenko, 30, was born in Russia and moved to New York with her family when she was 10. Ten years later, she fell in love with her Ukrainian husband, Andrey, and the couple now have a 6-year-old son. Ms. Gavrylchenko commutes from Brooklyn on the Q train each weekday morning to her job as an office manager. Though she returns to Russia
title: From Texas or Russia, Ohio or Colombia, Finding Themselves in New York

body: If you ask 100 people to guess the number of jelly beans in a big glass jar, few will come close. The average of their guesses, however, will be almost exactly right. That, in a nutshell, is the lesson of ''The Wisdom of Crowds,'' the best-selling book by James Surowiecki, The New Yorker magazine's business columnist. When it comes to quantifiable
title: ART REVIEW; 3,344 People May Not Know Art but Know What They Like

body: From the grinning funny face on the caps to the intricate labels designed by a tattoo artist, a collection of new beers by the Shmaltz Brewing Company of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., pays garish homage to Coney Island. The Sword Swallower, a steel-cut hop lager, is my favorite for its depth and bitterness. The Albino Python, a summery wheat beer, is
title: FOOD STUFF; Coney Island? I'll Drink to That

author: E-mail: cheers@nytimes.com
body: Ray D'Errico sat courtside last Sunday, his toes in the sand, with shards of sunlight and a volleyball logo adorning his shaved head. ''Volleyball is the greatest sport in the world,'' said D'Errico, staring through sunglasses at the men's finals of the A.V.P. Belmar Open. ''I got here on Thursday night and checked into a hotel seven blocks away
title: CHEERING SECTION; An Endless Summer Searching for the Perfect Spike

body: Around the Coney Island handball courts, the handball mecca of New York City, there was the usual thwock of rubber balls against concrete walls, sneakers sliding on sun-baked courts and raspy trash being talked among the players, many of whom had deep tans, taut bodies and egos big enough to play great playground handball. But there was also a buzz
title: Want to Play Handball? Better Not Forget Your Ego

body: When Walt Whitman crossed the East River on the Brooklyn Ferry, the sheer ecstasy of the trip made him see the future. It was us, the coming generations of urban dwellers who would draw the same energy he did from his wonderful town and its waterways. Whitman imagined an essence of city life that is still palpable -- and intoxicating -- no matter
title: ART REVIEW; Cascades, Sing the City Energetic

body: APPRECIATING the foods immigrants have brought to New York City is pretty easy for the visitor: pop a dumpling into your mouth or chomp on a taco and you get it: this thing tastes good. But checking out the imported and home-grown sports played around the city doesn't always provide instant satisfaction: someone needs to be there to explain what
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | NONMAINSTREAM SPORTS; Are You Ready for Some Gaelic Football?

body: Chapter 7: Dentist to the Stars Roger Corbett's 2008 appointment book began in the closing weeks of 2007. He'd blocked out a few days just after Christmas as ''kids at Mom's,'' followed by ''kids to La Guardia.'' I noticed several appointments with doctors, each preceded by ''call Mom to remind.'' So these were his mother's doctors he was dutifully
title: SUNDAY SERIAL | THE FUNNY PAGES; Mrs. Corbett's Request: Chapter 7: Dentist to the Stars

body: On Thursday night, the Callahans from Queens, still draped in Mets attire, were rooting for the Brooklyn Cyclones. It was the couple's first visit to KeySpan Park, where the minor-league Cyclones play, and Bill and Lisa Callahan had come to bask in the atmosphere of the waterfront stadium, to watch baseball with the borough's famed fanatics -- and
title: Not Ebbets Field, but Close Enough

body: It was a lefty-righty matchup for the ages. Make that a righty-lefty matchup for the ages. Pat Venditte, an ambidextrous pitcher for the Staten Island Yankees, eventually got the matchup he wanted: right-hander vs. right-hander, which resulted in a game-ending strikeout after a long and bizarre pitcher-batter sequence -- make that batter-pitcher
title: Double-Barreled Pitcher Provides Shot of Confusion

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites 'SUPERHEROES: FASHION AND FANTASY' LECTURE AND PANEL ''Shakespeare is not writing any new plays, but he's taught in classes everywhere. Comics may stop publishing tomorrow, but people can still study comics.'' So says Peter Coogan, the author of ''Superhero: The Secret Origin of a Genre.'' He founded the Institute for
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. title: Spare Times

author: E-mail: dwyer@nytimes.com
body: An interesting problem is what to do with the words and numbers ''$2 billion.'' Hardly anyone really knows what they mean. One example, worth repeating, is that the difference between a million and a billion seconds is the difference between 11 days and 33 years. A thousand seconds is 16 minutes. This week, word came that the Yankees want $250
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; High End Or Low, Ballparks Break Bank

body: FOR CHILDREN 'TAKE ME OUT TO THE BALL GAME: 1864' The games New Yorkers play may be infinite, but at least those on athletic fields are usually identifiable. Even sports fans, however, may scratch their heads over two contests in the Bronx on Saturday. The first involves a ball and bats, but no gloves, no helmets and strictly underhand pitching.
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: FOR CHILDREN 'THE BACKYARDIGANS LIVE! TALE OF THE MIGHTY KNIGHTS' (Friday through Sunday) So maybe your kids are too young for ''Spamalot.'' They can still enjoy medieval madness and foolery in this stage production, derived from the Nickelodeon preschool show ''The Backyardigans'' and a swashbuckling special the channel broadcast in January. This
title: For Children

body: INTERNATIONAL ONCE A BOTTLE IN NAPLES, Now Garbage in Hamburg Southern Italy has run out of places to put its trash, so a 56-car train arrives in Hamburg every day bearing 700 tons of Naples' garbage. Italy's problem has echoes in all of Europe, where Naples looks increasingly like a foul-smelling version of an untenable past, and Hamburg its
title: INSIDE THE TIMES: June 9, 2008

body: GOING to our local playground in Brooklyn can be painful. When friends are there, it's great. But it's hard to make small talk with people I barely know about high-tech strollers, whose kid is taking French lessons (mine are not), the pros and cons of gifted-and-talented programs -- the usual nightmare urban-mommy conversation. So, come late
title: SUMMER IN THE CITY; New York's Big Backyard

body: A mustang named Benny suffered a stone bruise. Dave, a Peruvian Paso, slipped and gouged his ankle. A thoroughbred named Sham, a former show horse, now needs regular hock injections for his stiffening joints. Fran Levy, their owner, said that Benny, Dave and Sham, along with countless other horses, have suffered injuries while trotting on the
title: For Riders and Mounts, Rough Going in Prospect Park

body: THE Tornado roller coaster, precursor and rival to the world-famous Cyclone, stood on the east side of Stillwell Avenue in Coney Island from 1926 until 1977, when it perished in a fire. More recently, that block, between Bowery Street and the Boardwalk, was home to a go-cart track and a cluster of batting cages. Then last spring, in preparation for
title: DISPATCHES; The Texas Carny and His Coney Island Gal

body: DEAR DIARY: I knew my friend Anne was better trained for the race when she turned to me in the sixth mile and asked, ''What would be a good side dish to serve with short ribs?'' We were on the bottom loop of Central Park on March 30, heading toward the finish of the 10k Scotland Run at Tavern on the Green. Anne is a finance geek with a Martha
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: FOR Maggie Tobin and Bob Mason, the last straw in Park Slope was the parking. The couple, who have two young children, lived there for eight years and loved being near Prospect Park and surrounded by friends. But when the time came to buy, they wanted more space and found the prices too high, and they decided they could also live without the ritual
title: LIVING IN KENSINGTON, BROOKLYN; Name From London, People From Everywhere

body: The Train to the Surf To the Editor: When David Gregorius was a resident at Maimonides Medical Center in Borough Park, Brooklyn ('' 'Scrubs' Near the D Train,'' May 11), he wrote an e-mail message to his friends saying, ''I live nowhere near the beach'' and describing a complicated subway ride to the Rockaways via Manhattan. It is true that to go
title: TO THE EDITOR; In Search of Waves, and a Memorable Star Turn

author: Mark Caldwell is the author of ''New York Night: The Mystique and Its History.''
body: Burlesque, that fabled if slightly soiled fantasy realm whose heraldic totem was the twirling pasty and whose undisputed queen was Gypsy Rose Lee, has returned to New York, dripping with rhinestones and trailing clouds of glitter. Under the rubric neo-burlesque, a Depression-era genre whose hallmarks were smut with attitude, bargain-barn glamour,
title: The Almost Naked City

body: KAMEN--Richard, passed away peacefully on May 14th after a long illness. Beloved brother of Mitchell. Dear uncle, devoted cousin and friend. Services today, 12 noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

author: Samuel G. Freedman is a professor of journalism at Columbia University. His e-mail is sgfreedman@nytimes.com.
body: Set just a few subway stops apart in blue-collar Brooklyn, drawing from a similar pool of new immigrants and American-born blacks, two high schools spent the past decade careering toward opposite destinies. The question now is whether the failure of one will destroy the success of the other. Since the late 1990s, Lafayette High School in the Bath
title: ON EDUCATION; Failings of One Brooklyn High School May Threaten a Neighbor's Success

body: IN the opening moments of Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest chapter of the cinematically styled video game franchise, two men are standing at the side of a boat, watching a familiar sight drift into view. Through their eyes, we see a digitized, 21st-century retelling of a scene that greeted numerous generations of new arrivals to an unknown country:
title: A Strange City Called Home

body: James Frederick was in Manhattan cycling west in the Prince Street bike lane on a recent morning when a green Ford parked in the lane forced him to swerve into the narrow roadway where cars and vans were rushing past. ''It's kind of scary because the cars next to you just keep going,'' said Mr. Frederick, 49, a messenger who lives in the
title: Bike Lanes, Intended for Safety, Become Traffic Battlegrounds

body: MY parents were volunteer emergency medical technicians for two decades, so I expected I would be great at the job. I certainly had parental support. When I mentioned to my mom in 1996 that I was thinking of becoming an E.M.T., she all but picked me up and carried me into the training hall, right down the block from our house on Eaton Court in
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; The Man In the Blue Pajamas

body: NEW YORK has long been a city of stand-up eaters, but that doesn't mean people aren't picky. To make it here, a sandwich has to work overtime, being portable, filling, interesting and tasty. ''What's better than a really great sandwich?'' said Alexandra Raij, the chef at Tía Pol and El Quinto Pino, who is hosting a sandwich potluck for friends at
title: The Next Best Things In Sliced Bread

body: I was rolling through the neon deluge of a place very like Times Square the other night in my Landstalker sport utility vehicle, listening to David Bowie's ''Fascination'' on the radio. The glittery urban landscape was almost enough to make me forget about the warehouse of cocaine dealers I was headed uptown to rip off. Soon I would get bored,
title: VIDEO GAME REVIEW | GRAND THEFT AUTO IV; Forget It, Niko, It's Liberty City, a Dystopian Dream

body: IT was the spring of 1996. The three of us had spent a pleasant afternoon on the Brighton Beach Boardwalk at the famed Russian restaurant Tatiana: my grandmother, she was alive then; my Aunt Deena, we were on tentative speaking terms that year before her death; and I, the only granddaughter. title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; The Fire, and the Mystery

title: City's Coney Island Design Revised to Break Deadlock

title: Spare Times: For Children

The 2002 raid on the sprawling Cypress Hills housing project in East New York, said Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, shut down ''a historic
title: Conspiracy and Compromise

author: Andrew Rice is a contributing writer to The New York Times Magazine.
body: THE KELLER HOTEL, an old seaman's inn, has seen a few tides come and go. An Irish coal merchant constructed it in the late 1890s along a salty stretch of the Greenwich Village waterfront, at a time when the docks there were some of the busiest in the world. During the Depression, the Keller served as a flophouse for out-of-work sailors, who boozed
title: The Tightwad's Legacy

body: FOR CHILDREN 'PIGS, BEARS AND BILLY GOATS GRUFF' To children a kitchen is much more than a place for cooking and eating. Forks and spoons double as percussion instruments; pans serve as warriors' helmets; a tabletop is a cottage roof. Where grown-ups see only mealtime, the young see playtime. But the adults of the Patch Theater Company have no such
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: INTERNATIONAL BUSH SUPPORTS UKRAINE NATO BID, Risking Collision with Russia President Bush expressed strong support for Ukraine's attempt to join the NATO alliance. His stand risked a diplomatic confrontation with Russia even as the administration sought an agreement with President Vladimir V. Putin over American missile defenses in Europe. It also
title: INSIDE THE TIMES

body: A man and a woman were stabbed to death Tuesday morning in a Brooklyn apartment during a dispute involving them and another man, the police said, and the second man was later arrested. The reason for the dispute was not immediately clear, but the second man, Angel Valentin, 36, was arrested Tuesday night on murder and weapons charges, the police
title: Two People Stabbed to Death In an Apartment in Brooklyn

body: Bertha, a sand tiger shark who had lived at the New York Aquarium since the 1960s and was believed to be one of the oldest sharks in any aquarium in the world, died on Saturday. In announcing Bertha's death, the Wildlife Conservation Society, which oversees the aquarium, said on Tuesday that she was believed to be at least 43 years old. ''There was
title: In Coney Island, One of the Oldest Sharks in Captivity Dies

body: SCHNEIWEISS--Hynda Lessman , survived by husband Saul, brother Morton, many nieces, nephews and cousins. Born 1925, Chicago. Lived in Midwood, Brooklyn, last 66 years. Active in community. title: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHNEIWEISS, HYNDA LESSMAN

body: IT was the cats that caused Tania Dudina and George Kokoris to think about buying a place. Last spring, the couple, living in a studio in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, adopted two cats. One had ringworm, a skin fungus. The cats, Loki and Pliooshka, needed months of treatment with medications, ointments and shampoos. They had to be kept apart, too, lest
title: THE HUNT; More Than a Pet Project

title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Of Bikes and Railings Q. I see signs affixed to subway entrances that state that it is illegal to lock ''anything'' to the outside stair railings. title: F. Y. I.

body: THE New York Aquarium is a notoriously unwelcoming structure: a walled seaside compound with no sea view and a parking lot for an entrance. All that seemed about to change in October 2006, when the city announced three finalists in a design competition to reshape the aquarium's exterior. ''The aquarium can be iconic,'' Joshua Sirefman, then interim
title: CONEY ISLAND; 300,000 Gallons Of 'Jaws'

body: Living With Music To the Editor: Via Dwight Garner's Inside the List column (March 9), I learned that one of my homemade mix tapes was being sold online for -- jeez -- $500. I gave away these cassettes, along with guitar picks and posters, at each stop on tour for my novel, ''Beautiful Children.'' This was done to thank people for caring about
title: Letters

body: Jennifer McSweeney The Penny McCall Foundation was established in 1987 by McCall and her husband, David, to support contemporary artists, writers and curators. title: Ladies Who Launch

title: VICTORIAN FLATBUSH; Peaked Roofs, Crossed Fingers

title: Car Crash Stops Subway Service

title: Paid Notice: Deaths MOSKOWITZ, THEODORE

author: More Dispatches: nytimes.com/cityroom
body: IT was just after 6 on a recent Tuesday evening, but Coney Island was so dark it could have been midnight. The Nathan's sign was on, but the service windows facing the sidewalk were closed. title: DISPATCHES; The Boardwalk and the Bling

author: COLSON WHITEHEAD IS A FELLOW AT THE CULLMAN CENTER FOR SCHOLARS AND WRITERS. HIS NOVEL ''SAG HARBOR'' WILL BE PUBLISHED NEXT YEAR.
body: I live in Brooklyn. I moved here 14 years ago for the cheap rent. It was a little embarrassing because I was raised in Manhattan, and so I was a bit of a snob about the other boroughs. At the time there was a big buzz about the ''Black Renaissance'' of Fort Greene. It was one big house party thrown by Spike Lee and Branford Marsalis, Rosie Perez
title: ESSAY; I WRITE IN BROOKLYN. GET OVER IT.

body: ART 'YEAR OF THE RAT' Kim Jones's war-torn, fluently hybrid art is more germane than ever, as proved by his latest exhibition at Pierogi. His primary theme, directly or indirectly, is war and its toxic effects, a subject inspired partly by his experiences as a marine in Vietnam. title: Museum and Gallery Listings

body: FOR CHILDREN 'ON TOP OF SPAGHETTI' In a Queens theater recently, minutes before showtime, a student of about 6 was doing what most small children do in an auditorium: everything but keep still. body: Verrazano Light Show Q. I have a view of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge from my building. When I turn in around 11 p.m., the lights on the bridge are green. body: FOR CHILDREN 'READY FOR ACTION!' For a parent Sesame Street Live doesn't have quite the charm of ''Sesame Street'' on television. You lose the intimacy of the close-ups with the cheery characters, and the noise -- including the loud bangs of containers of confetti bursting over the audience's heads -- may make you long for a remote control. But
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: ART 'NINA IN POSITION' Maybe as fallout from last summer's liberatingly eccentric Documenta 12, we've seen a handful of intriguing and enigmatic group shows in New York this season, spun around opaque themes and designed to generate psychic atmosphere. The persuasive ''Nina in Position'' at Artists Space, organized by Jeffrey Uslip, is the latest.
title: Art

body: On Design Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street; (212) 849-8400. body: New York City went to court on Tuesday seeking to undo a 1974 desegregation order for a middle school in southwest Brooklyn, arguing that the ruling was outdated and no longer reflected the racial mix of the neighborhood. The original court order for Mark Twain Intermediate School was imposed when the region, District 21, was overwhelmingly white.
title: City Moves To Overturn 1974 Ruling On Race

body: A homemade silencer found lying in some leaves. Bingo. Fingerprints on the silencer that led to a suspect. Bingo. Phone calls, lots and lots of them, between the suspected gunman and the estranged wife of the slain man. Triple bingo. So it went last fall, into winter and through last week as detectives worked to solve the Oct. 28 killing of Dr.
title: In Dentist's Death, Clues Line Up After a Big Break

body: FOR CHILDREN 'THE BUTTERFLY' Sevrine, a child during World War II, never became a famous historical figure. Unlike Anne Frank, she did not keep a diary about her experiences as a Jew in hiding. Her life has never been a subject for Broadway. But her story and that of Monique, a Roman Catholic girl who befriended her, is finding a widening audience,
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: It was a day when, beyond all else, New York and its suburbs finally seemed to matter. Candidates' supporters stood outside polling stations calling out encouragement to voters who already seemed enlivened by the mood. title: Area Voters Savor Rare Feeling: A Suspenseful Primary

body: On a winter day in 2005, an undercover officer noticed two young men loitering on a street corner in Gravesend, Brooklyn. Something about their behavior caught his eye. He approached the men, gave one of them $19 and was handed two bags of crack cocaine by the other. After he left, other officers moved in and arrested them. In the spring of 2007,
title: In Brooklyn, Police Work Is Undone by Scandal

body: FOR CHILDREN 'MEDIEVAL CHILDREN' Childhood in the Middle Ages tended to be short. If calamity didn't end it (remember the Black Death?), adult responsibilities often did. body: When the police were criticized last spring for arresting 32 young people in Bushwick, Brooklyn, who were on their way to a wake for a friend who had been killed, they said the youths had been threatening public safety -- blocking traffic, climbing on cars, wearing T-shirts and flashing signs in homage to their friend's status as a gang leader.
title: Charges Dropped for 22 Arrested on Way to Wake

body: Working as an undercover narcotics officer is among the most dangerous jobs on the police force. You have to pretend to be an addict and win the trust of dealers. title: Undercover Work Seen as Mix of Art, Temptation and, Sometimes, Corruption

body: SHERMAN--Arnold E. Beloved husband of Naomi S. Sherman. Loving father of William and Jane Sherman, Patty and Richard Rudolph, and Joseph and Lisa Sherman. Cherished grandfather of David, Michael, Jason, Vicky, Andrew, Sam and Nathan. Devoted brother of Florence Hartenstein and brother-in-law of Ruth Kotcher. Dear uncle, great-uncle and friend.
